Generation III.Ruby: Lotad live in ponds and lakes, where they float on the surface. It grows weak if its broad leaf dies. On rare occasions, this Pok é mon travels on land in search of clean water.
Generation III.Sapphire: Lotad is said to have dwelled on land before. However, this Pok é mon is thought to have returned to water because the leaf on its head grew large and heavy. It now lives by floating atop the water.
Generation III.Emerald: This Pok é mon lives in ponds with clean water. It is known to ferry small Pok é mon across ponds by carrying them on the broad leaf on its head.
Generation III.FireRed: It searches about for clean water. If it does not drink water for too long, the leaf on its head wilts.
Generation III.LeafGreen: It searches about for clean water. If it does not drink water for too long, the leaf on its head wilts.

Generation IV.Diamond: It looks like an aquatic plant and serves as a ferry to Pokémon that can't swim.
Generation IV.Pearl: It looks like an aquatic plant and serves as a ferry to Pokémon that can't swim.
Generation IV.Platinum: It looks like an aquatic plant and serves as a ferry to Pokémon that can't swim.
Generation IV.HeartGold: Its leaf grew too large for it to live on land. That is how it began to live floating in the water.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: Its leaf grew too large for it to live on land. That is how it began to live floating in the water.

Generation VI.Y: It searches about for clean water. If it does not drink water for too long, the leaf on its head wilts.

Generation VIII.Sword: It searches about for clean water. If it does not drink water for too long, the leaf on its head wilts.
Generation VIII.Shield: Its leaf grew too large for it to live on land. That is how it began to live floating in the water.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It looks like an aquatic plant and serves as a ferry for Pokémon that can't swim.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It looks like an aquatic plant and serves as a ferry for Pokémon that can't swim.

Generation IX.Scarlet: The leaf on its head is naturally dirt repellent and will stay clean even after transporting Pokémon that are covered in mud.
Generation IX.Violet: Lotad will gather in lakes that have good water quality. The surfaces of the lakes sometimes become covered in Lotad leaves.

Generation IV.HeartGold: Safari Zone (Desert with 8 Waterside points; Plains with 12 Waterside points)
Generation IV.SoulSilver: Safari Zone (Desert with 8 Waterside points; Plains with 12 Waterside points)

Generation VIII.Shield: Route 2 , Rolling Fields , Dappled Grove , West Lake Axewell Bridge Field , Dappled Grove , Stony Wilderness ( Max Raid Battle )
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: Grand Underground - Grassland Cave , Riverbank Cave , Fountainspring Cave , Sunlit Cavern , Still-Water Cavern (After obtaining the National Pokédex )

Generation IX.The Hidden Treasure of Area Zero: Apple Hills , Reveler's Road , Oni Mountain , Infernal Pass , Wistful Fields , Paradise Barrens , Kitakami Wilds , Timeless Woods Tera Raid Battles ( 2★ )
